e4: No, because while honest reporting is preferable, it may lead to short-term advantages for sophisticated investors who correctly adjust their expectations, potentially putting small or retail investors at a disadvantage.
e5: An ethical reporting policy should accurately report financial information, be transparent and disclose any material impacts, provide all stakeholders with an equal advantage, avoid exploiting cognitive biases or uneven access to information, and prioritize fairness and justice for smaller/retail investors. In this context, the company should consider whether more education or adjustment aids could help reduce disparities between investor groups.
e6: Would implementing a more nuanced accounting policy for earnings adjustments improve market conditions and help bridge the knowledge gap between different types of investors? Are there plans to re-educate or communicate the new accounting treatment effectively?
